fields.summary: Provide a configuration option in 'Update from date' dialog that allows items with no remaining estimate to remain open

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-322].
  {panel}

We had this problem:
- we estimate a story and create a linked issue
- the developer creates some subtasks and estimates them
- we "update from date" the plan
--> story estimation in portfolio is increased, which is good. 
- we "apply update to project"
--> the estimation on the issue is increased to the sum of original estimation and subtasks
- we "update from date" again
--> the estimation on the portfolio is now set to the sum of estimation and subtasks, which are counted double now

This feedback will repeat and increase the story estimation endlessly. Also it cannot be solved by setting the estimation on the issue to zero - after two loops there will be the same effect.

When activating the "sync" option, it seems to be even worse, as the feedback will happen more often. We had estimations going up to a few hundred hours in a day or two.
fields.summary: Estimates of Stories with estimated Subtasks increase in a feedback loop

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-320].
  {panel}

As a user, I would like to make an independent copy of an existing plan. 

This would allow:
* Rapid exploration of proposed changes to a schedule, without loss of the original schedule.
* Rapid preparation of several candidate schedules with different prioritizations.

The user interface could be a "Copy" operation added to the items in Portfolio>Manage Plans, similar to the copy operations elsewhere in JIRA.
fields.summary: Copy a plan
Sprint Filter

fields.description:
I was excited to see that the facility to add global non-working days has been implemented in Portfolio On Demand (Cloud), however when I entered all the UK bank holidays as global absences and removed them as individual member absences the capacities look different.

I would expect 1 day to have the same impact on a team member's capacity regardless of whether it is an individual absence or a global absence but this is not the case.

The bank holidays I added were
04 May 2015
25 May 2015
31 Aug 2015
25 Dec 2-15
28 Dec 2015

As you can see for sprints 3, 6, 20, 36 and 37 the capacities are different. Where there is one day of holiday in a sprint as a global absence the capacity for this team member is 3.2 story points (typically 5), whereas as an individual absence it is 4 story points.

I would expect it to be 4 story points as there are 5 working days set in the plan (Mon - Fri), and one of these working days is an absence/non-working day, so the overall capacity should be reduced by 20%.
fields.summary: Global Non-working Days results in different capacity to adding absences for individuals
Untick 'Version Name' per default in 'Apply Updates to Projects' dialog

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-316].
  {panel}

Add a column to the backlog to view the Estimates (story points, original time, and remaining time) of the issue(s) that are linked to the Portfolio Epic/Story. 
This would total all the linked issues and their children (sub-tasks, epic sub-issues). 

This would allow more specific comparisons between the estimate in Portfolio and the estimate on the issues.

If there are multiple issues linked to the Portfolio item, maybe the tool tip can display the totals per linked issue.
fields.summary: Add backlog column - Issue Estimate

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-315].
  {panel}

SYSTEM:

JIRA portfolio version: 1.9.2
JIRA version: 6.3.15

SCENARIO:
* Our "definition of done" is typical. Both implementation and testing must occur for a story to be complete. 
* Although there is some back-and-forth, the bulk of those two activities occur in two distinct, sequential stages.
* We want most stories to be completed in a single sprint.
* As suggested by "Understanding Stages and Skills" at https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=715262985, we are using stages for sequential activities. 

>"Typically, stages are used for activities that need to be done sequentially per work item."
>...
>"Another likely setup could be: 
>"* Design
>"* Implementation
>"* Test"

* In "Configure stages and skills," I've created two stages: "Development" and "QA."
* On the "People" page, I've created a team with two people, one checked for each stage. 
* On the "Backlog" page, I've created a single story, assigned to that team.
* To allow both stages to be scheduled within a single sprint, I've turned off the "stage/sprint constraints" in the plan configuration accessed via "Plan>Configure," on the page accessed with "Planning>Scheduling."
* I've configured the schedule views at the bottom so that "Grouping" is by "Members."
* I've examined the Epics, Stories and Capacity views.

EXPECTED:
* The QA stage will occur, and should be scheduled, after the development stage.

OBSERVED:
* The QA and development stages are displayed as concurrent, at least in the Epics, Stories and Capacity views.
fields.summary: Stages scheduled concurrently rather than sequentially

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-314].
  {panel}

I want to be able to import all new stories from JIRA whose parent Epic is already in Portfolio.

My situation:
- I have a lot of stuff in JIRA that I don't want imported into Portfolio
- In JIRA Portfolio, I onlynwant to track a specific set of Epics and all their child Stories (i.e. the ones the business cares about most, and where resourcing matters most)
- Over time, as requirements evolve, new Stories are created in JIRA, and unless I can import these the plan will be wrong

The problem:
- When I go to import issues, I only want to see the ones that belong to an already imported Epic.
- There is no filter I can write that will select only those issues whose parent is already imported in JIRA Portfolio.
fields.summary: Ability to import only issues whose Epic is in Portfolio already
Assign more than one initiative to a team in parallel
Define if epics within an initiative are spread across teams or limited
Import releases from custom field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-310].
  {panel}

*Scenario* : 
When one user is allocated to multiple projects/sprints at the same time (full time), then JIRA Portfolio does not give any indication of that to the administrator. It is possible to plan a user in multiple projects at the same time without getting any warning.

*Suggestion* : 
When you add a user to a team, Portfolio should indicate available hours based on the team members allocation to other teams. There should also be a way to clearly view the users allocation in all the other teams.

If a user is allocated for 40 hours in 2 teams, then there should be a warning message to make the user aware of this situation. To further add on, it would be best if we could have the visibility the total number of hours available for the team to ease on the scheduling and planning as well.
fields.summary: Clear visibility of available hours per team member

fields.description:
The backlog column settings aren't saved when the same plan is opened by different users.

*Example* 
* On my plan, I hide all columns except for "Theme"
* Another user opens my plan
* The other user sees a different set of columns

Screenshot is attached.
fields.summary: Backlog column settings don't transfer between different users in the same plan

fields.description:
When importing issues into portfolio, if you deselect an epic, all issues that would be imported with that epic as a parent lose their links to do. Reselecting that epic does not restore this.

This is especially frustrating when you have a long list and only a few epics/stories to import and you start by deselecting all. You then need to manually reselect the parent issue for all the stories you want to import.

This has caught new adopters by making them think it wasn't possible to import the link between Stories and Epics, since the first thing they did was deselect all and never saw the link there.

*Steps to replicate*:

Open issue import screen, ensuring there are Stories and Epics with links between them on that screen. Deselect all, or deselect a single Epic, watch all the links to deselected epics disappear (expected). Reselect the epic, or all issues, and notice how it's now a manual task to re-attach them all (undesirable).

*Workaround*:

Cancel import and start again, taking care not to deselect any of the epics you are wishing to import. Or manually re-connect the links.
fields.summary: Deselecting an epic during import loses links to that epic

fields.description:
It looks like if you update the name of a Portfolio-linked JIRA Version outside of Portfolio, and then do a sync in Portfolio, Portfolio changes the name back.

* Create a JIRA Version (Name "Release 4/15")
* Create a JIRA Portfolio Release
* Link them together in JIRA Portfolio
* From the JIRA Project Admin area, change the name of the Version (From "Release 4/15" to "2.1.0")
* Back in JIRA Portfolio, hit "Apply Updates"
* Notice the JIRA Version name has been changed back to "Release 4/15"

*Workaround* Delete the link in JIRA Portfolio, and add it again

_Related Issues_ There also doesn't seem to be a way to resync these JIRA Portfolio with changes from outside Portfolio manually. See JPO-156
fields.summary: JIRA Portfolio holds onto Version names tenaciously

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-298].
  {panel}

Hi,

I'm not sure how this is supposed to work, it causes a lot of confusion here. We have about 20 Projects, which we enter as Initiatives. For these we enter epics and stories. All this is happening in the "Initiatives" view. We never even open the "Epics" view, because it's just a chaotic collection of epics without context. 
Now we prioritize by dragging up and down the initiatives and the release streams. 
What happens is: priority is not adjusted as we want, because the priority in the epics view (which we don't use) is overruling it.  
From my perspective the priorities between initiatives (on the initiatives view) have no effect at all. Whats the concept behind this?

Thanks, Juri

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 24 March 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!
 
Thanks,
Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

Just like in JIRA Agile where the user has the ability to prioritize issues among different issues, I'd like to have the same feature on JIRA Portfolio backlog. 

Scenario: When managing my backlog I noticed that there is an issue within an epic that needs to have a higher priority. So, I decided I want this specific issue on another epic with higher priority. JIRA Portfolio should allow me to "move" these issues around.
fields.summary: Allow individual issues priorization among different epics

We have 2 projects with different workflows and progress setting (in Portfolio) by resolved issues. 
In first case Workflow starts from Open and finishes on Closed states and Progress lines work correct (update while creating and closing).

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-286].
  {panel}

As a JIRA Portfolio administrator
I would like disable "Everybody" as permission access to new plans in my platform
so that authorized users must be input on a per-plan basis and then the list of plans for every user only includes the ones strictly interesting for him/her.

Even though the option "Private (only me)" is the default in the creation dialog, many users may be tempted to use "Everybody", as it suggests an easy access for colleagues. In large instances, using "Everybody" creates long lists of uninteresting plans for most users.

Having or not "Everybody" in the plan creation dialog could ideally be set as an administrative feature at platform level.
As a complementary feature, plans could allow admins to turn them back to be "Private (only me)"
fields.summary: Possibility to disable "Everybody" as permission access to a plan

fields.description:
To reproduce:
- In JIRA:
-- Create epic with 2 stories
- In Portfolio:
-- Set "Keep backlog items in sync" for all issue types
-- Import into Portfolio
- Back in JIRA:
-- Create a new epic in JIRA, and move one of the stories to it

Expected behaviour:
- Portfolio should each Epic as having one story

Actual behaviour:
- First epic has both stories, even if you update the plan from JIRA

This is really annoying, as I can't keep my epics in sync and have little faith I'm looking at the right information for any epic in either tool.
fields.summary: Moving stories between Epics in JIRA does not sync to Portfolio

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-276].

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 24 March 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!
 
Thanks,
Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

When pushing update via *Plan > Apply updates to project/s*, despite all items under Update linked elements are selected, the Epic-Story links are not updated.

Steps to reproduce:
* Import Story and Epics from JIRA
* Create new Epic and corresponding JIRA Epic using Portfolio
* Move existing Story under new Epic using Portfolio
* Click Plan > Apply updates to projects/s

Current Behaviour
* New JIRA Epic does not link with the JIRA Story
* The JIRA Story still links with original JIRA Epic

Expected Behaviour
* The JIRA Story should now linked with the new JIRA Epic created from Portfolio
fields.summary: "Apply update to projects" should provide an option to sync Epic/Story relationships

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-268].
  {panel}

The use case we frequently have is: 
- 2 or more team members should be scheduled to work on one task, at the same time (if possible). 

In the same way that Portfolio can create and link one JIRA issue per stage, it would be great to have one issue per skill, with one dedicated assignee each. Portfolio should then try to schedule these at the same time, just like it does for Epic bundles now. 

What we do at the moment is create 2 stories/issues, and put them into the same release, and hope they get scheduled at the same time. This kind of works, but puts some wrong functionality in the release stream.
fields.summary: Create and link multiple JIRA issues per story, one for each skill

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-264].
  {panel}

The first 'Update from date...' that was run after issues were imported wanted to update the status (Issue JPO-263) and the estimated time.
For the issues that were already complete, it was going to set the estimated time to 0 hours. Not wanting to apply these values to the completed issues, I only selected the status for updating, unchecking all other fields.

This updated the status. I then tried to run the 'Update from date..' again now that the completed items were no longer listed. I intended to pull in the estimated time changes, but the changes were no longer listed. 

This was frustrating and I could not find a way to get the current estimate time into Portfolio. Even new changes made to the 'original time estimate' and 'remaining time estimate' would not appear. I think this is because the occurred in the same day as the last update, but I don't know the logic it uses for finding changes.
fields.summary: Allow running 'Update from date...' sequentially for different fields

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-258].
  {panel}

In the Epics backlog, I have some projects that I would like to keep in our backlog, but that we aren't prioritizing yet.  This helps to keep these projects on our radar when we are choosing which projects to prioritize.  Currently, I manually set these to be in the "Later" release, but I'd also like to keep them at the bottom of our backlog to unclutter our view of the scheduled projects.  

Unfortunately, if I add epics to use the normal "Create Epic" button, it puts the newly created epic below all of those items that are in the "Later" release.  Thus, it would be great to have some of the following:
- Instead of requiring me to drag and drop (which can be finicky when dragging to the bottom of the list), it would be nice to also be able to manually edit the priority number (i.e. type in "5").
- Expose an option like in Jira Agile backlog, where I can right click and then click "Send to bottom of backlog."
- Allow me to use command/shift click to highlight multiple rows that I can then drag as a group.
- Or, best of all, allow me to keep all of my "Later" items in a specific grouping that sticks to the bottom of the backlog.  It would make sense that if I'm specifically scheduling something for "Later" that it would be at the bottom of the backlog anyhow.
fields.summary: Make it easier to manage "Later" items

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-250].
  {panel}

The current Themes functionality allows each Story to be tagged with at most one Theme. The explanation in the doco is that this avoids the problem of double-counting effort.
The trouble with this constraint is that there are cases where double-counting is exactly what I want to be able to do.
To demonstrate by extreme, say my plan consists of just one Story - "Deliver technical report". Say my business objectives are represented as two themes - "Satisfy customers" and "Grow knowledge-base". Why shouldn't I be able to assign both themes to the story and then have my Themes report show a 50/50 split?
In other words, when a Story is assigned to two themes, just add that story's effort to both themes and let the normalisation-across-themes takes care of it when charted.

Note that this suggestion is independent of JPO-249.
fields.summary: Allow Story to contribute to multiple Themes
Allow orthogonal Themes

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-245].
  {panel}

To reproduce:
- add 2 work items, add a dependency
- assign to different team members, Kanban mode
- disable "Dependent story constraint"

expected: 
One item should be scheduled after the other. The description of the option is "Forces dependent stories to be placed in separate sprints.", so I dont expect this to have any effect on a Kanban schedule.

what happens:
The 2 items are scheduled at the same time, breaking the dependency
fields.summary: Option "Dependent story constraint" breaks scheduling in Kanban Mode

fields.description:
h3. Problem
The estimate of imported tasks or allready estimated ones, will not get recalculated, when you change the Planning unit.
h3. How it affects us
We usually plan in days, but sometimes in small projects, we are planning in hours. When we start on a small project or a big one and than we find out it is going to be the other Planning unit, we have to go and rewrite all the existing estimates by hand and this can be really annoying.
fields.summary: Switching Planning unit will not recalculate estimate
Requesting capability to have stories with different stages and skills.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-230].
  {panel}

It would be great to be able to filter the report by a time window, especially for reporting.  Or being able to use it to zoom in on a part of a plan. For instance I would like to be able to find out what percentage of effort was spent on themes for a certain time window (like Q1, Q2, etc).

There are two hacks I can think of:
-Add a release to all streams and assign anything that starts in Q1 to that release.  Then do reporting by the release.

-Label initiatives with a prefix (like Q1-Go to Moon) and then filter by that prefix.  

Both of these are really approximate as releases or initiatives bleed into Q2 from Q1.

Or is there another way to do this?
fields.summary: Time Window Filter

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-229].
  {panel}

In our JIRA instance we set 1d = 7h.
This setting is not considered in Portfolio, that still assumes 1d = 8h.
*This mismatch makes the "Apply updates to project" set wrong estimates in JIRA*.

For instance, if I estimate a story to 2d in Portfolio, this is applied in JIRA as 2d 2h. When I set 2d in Portofolio, I assume this means 14h, because so I set the Time Tracking setting at system level.
If not, what is the purpose of setting a system Time Tracking?
fields.summary: 1d in Portfolio may not be 1d in JIRA ?!

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-223].
  {panel}

h4. Problem Definition
At the moment, Epic can only be assigned to a single team. The same rule applied to team assignment in initiative as well. For each epic (broken down from initiative) or story (broken down from epic), only one team can be assigned to it.

h4. Suggested Solution
It would be great to have the option to allow epic / initiative assignment to multiple teams and resources.
fields.summary: Allow epic assignment to multiple teams and resources
